Description: BioTelemetry Inc., a heart monitoring company headquartered in Malvern, Pennsylvania, agreed to pay $6.4 million to resolve allegations made under the False Claims Act that its subsidiary, CardioNet, overbilled Medicare and other federal health programs for Mobile Cardiac Outpatient Telemetry services when those services were not reasonable or medically necessary.
LifeWatch Services Inc., a Rosemont, Ill.-based company, agreed to pay the United States $18.5 million to resolve allegations that the company submitted false claims to federal health care programs.

After it disclosed conduct to the Office of Inspector General pursuant to its Corporate Integrity Agreement, LifeWatch Services, Inc. agreed to pay $737,572.50 for allegedly violating the Civil Monetary Penalties Law by submitting claims to Medicare for Ambulatory Cardiac Telemetry services for which there was no supporting medical record documentation.
Agency: Health & Human Services Department Office of Inspector General
Labor Department Wage and Hour Division
NAICS Translation: 621399: Offices of All Other Miscellaneous Health Practitioners
Info Source: March 7, 2017 download of a dataset posted by the Wage and Hour Division at https://enforcedata.dol.gov/views/data_summary.php
Notes: Date and year are the Findings End Date in the dataset posted by the Wage and Hour Division, which does not provide case opening or closing dates. The company name is the Legal Name provided by the dataset unless that field is blank, in which case the Trade Name is used. The dataset provides only one address and does not indicate whether it is the company headquarters address or the establishment address. The penalty amount is the total of civil monetary penalties and mandated back wages. The original dataset provides a breakdown.

Company: Philips Electronics of North America Corporation

Description: Respironics Inc., based in Murrysville, Pennsylvania, agreed to pay $34.8 million to resolve alleged False Claims Act violations for paying kickbacks in the form of free call center services to durable medical equipment suppliers that bought its masks for patients with sleep apnea.

Primary Offense: off-label or unapproved promotion of medical products
Secondary Offense: drug or medical equipment safety violation
Description: Spectranetics Corporation, a medical device manufacturer, agreed to pay the United States $4.9 million in civil damages plus a $100,000 forfeiture to resolve claims against the company arising from allegations that the company illegally imported unapproved medical devices and provided them to physicians for use in patients, conducted a clinical study in a manner that failed to comply with federal regulations and promoted certain products for procedures for which the company had not received Food and Drug Administration approval or clearance.

Info Source: from a spreadsheet posted on the FAA website at https://www.faa.gov/about/office_org/headquarters_offices/ash/ash_programs/hazmat/compliance_enforcement/

Private Litigation Case Title: Huey Nguyen v. Philips Electronics North America Corporation et al
Ramsey et al v. Philips North America LLC

Description: The Washington Attorney General announced that Philips agreed to pay $7 million as part of the AG's price-fixing lawsuit against seven manufacturers of cathode ray tubes, or CRTs, from 1995 to 2007.

Respironics agreed to pay $660,000 to settle multistate litigation alleging False Claims Act violations for paying kickbacks in the form of free call center services to durable medical equipment suppliers that bought its masks for patients with sleep apnea. This was part of a larger $34.8 million settlement involving the federal government; see the Violation Tracker entry at https://violationtracker.goodjobsfirst.org/violation-tracker/-respironics-inc

Philips agreed to provide customers vouchers in an unspecified amount and pay $2.5 million in legal fees and expenses to resolve a class action multidistrict litigation accusing the company and other baby bottle manufacturers of selling products with bisphenol-A (BPA).
Private Litigation Case Title: In Re: Bisphenol-A (BPA) Polycarbonate Plastic Products Liability Litigation
